title: gitgitgithub
text:
This tutorial will help you master GitHub for data science projects.
Mini-survey: https://forms.gle/VU6QLeoZqefbybKk6



Git basics
GitHub’s repositories management
Collaboration workflows

title: About git/github
text:
Version control
“Version control is the software engineering practice of controlling, organizing, and tracking different versions in history of computer files – primarily source code text files, but generally any type of file. (…) Version control includes options to view old versions and to revert a file to a previous version.” (Wikipedia, 2026 Jan)
Why this is so important? Because it can solve (or mitigate) several common problems when coding, for instance: overwriting a script or pipeline, needing to go back to a previous version, collaborating with others, tracking who what and when changes.
After this tutorial you will see that version control is much more effective than:

Manual copies: document_v1.txt, document_v2_final.txt, document_v2_final_really.txt
Commenting out code: leaving old code “just in case”
Physical notebooks
Shared network drives: the infamous “Final_FINAL.zip”

Initially version control was addressed as a client-server approach (centralized), however the distributed version control systems are much flexible and it follows a peer-to-peer approach. That is, “the complete codebase, including its full history, is mirrored on every developer’s computer. Compared to centralized version control, this enables automatic management branching and merging, speeds up most operations (except pushing and fetching), improves the ability to work offline, and does not rely on a single location for backups. Git, the world’s most popular version control system, is a distributed version control system.” (Wikipedia, 2026 Jan)


Git

It was initially developed by Linus Torvalds after the free license for BitKeeper was revoked for Linux. Git aims:

speed
data integrity
non-linear workflows (e.g., parallel branches running on different computers)

“Git maintains a local copy of the entire repository, also known as the repo, with history and version-tracking abilities, independent of network access or a central server. A repository is stored on each computer in a standard directory with additional, hidden files to provide version control capabilities. Git provides features to synchronize changes between repositories that share history; for asynchronous collaboration, this extends to repositories on remote machines. Although all repositories (with the same history) are peers, developers often use a central server to host a repository to hold an integrated copy.” (Wikipedia, 2026 Jan)


GitHub

Git has some limitations to collaborate online. For example: repos’ maintainers receive contributions (patches) mainly through email, merging depends on the maintainers, limited permission management, etc. Github is a software development platform that sits on top of Git, adding new features, such as:

Fork & Pull Request model: lowered barrier to contribution
Web-based interface: made Git accessible
Social features: stars, followers, trending repos
Issue tracking & Wikis: all-in-one project management
GitHub Pages: free hosting for documentation/projects

The impact:

2008: GitHub launches
2012: 2.1 million repositories
2015: 10 million repositories
2018: Microsoft acquires GitHub for $7.5B
Today: 100+ million developers, 420+ million repositories

title: GitHub
text:
Although Git precedes GitHub, it may be more useful to start with GitHub because is more user-friendly for beginners.


First of all, you will need a github account.

Go to github.com
Sign up for free

For academic purposes, GitHub offers additional features (https://github.com/education).
Explore the dashboard and your github.com/yourusername site. Explore also the site of someone else.



This is an empty repository:
 Nevertheless, I suggest you to add some features from the begining. Relevant features to take into account:

Name: incompatibilities… but names are very important
Description/README
Licence: depending on the context it may be really important.

https://choosealicense.com/
https://choosealicense.com/appendix/





Let’s add a bit of code: https://r4ds.had.co.nz/ https://github.com/BrainMapINB

Upload it through the repo’s uploader.
Always follow this basic steps: add -> commit -> push
Check the commit.



Add new code to that file. And upload again. Check the commit info.
Edit some code in that file. And upload again. Check the commit info. Tip: https://r-graph-gallery.com
You may also check the history of the “main”. You may view the entire previous version through the “…View file” option.
Another option would be to create a new branch based on a previous commit. Branches aim alternative or experimental pathways.


 Source: https://pdh11.blogspot.com/2013/09/a-git-workflow-at-ei.html



Merging a branch into the main branch is possible through “Compare & pull request”. Rebasing instead of merging, will imply discarding the changes added into the main branch after the aforementioned branch.


In general, the GitHub web interface face many limitations and it is very inefficient when considering multiple files. Let’s move to integrate the repository with Git commands.

title: gitgitgithub
text:
Scientific context

Square one: “Hackaton” https://doi.org/10.1186/s13742-016-0121-x
R package: https://doi.org/10.32614/CRAN.package.NBR https://doi.org/10.7554/eLife.55081
Another academic “hackaton”: https://neurohackademy.org/

Great overview: https://neurohackademy.org/course/from-interactive-exploration-to-reproducible-data-science-jupyter-binder-travis-and-friends-2/
Nice example with great tips: https://neurohackademy.org/course/tbd-4/

title: Be Git
text:
Main features of Git:
How Does Git Work?
The git directory serves as the database where the project’s complete history is stored, and GitHub fits for that.

title: Be Git
text:
Go to github.com
Sign up for free

title: Be Git
text:
First of all: get Git!

OS: https://git-scm.com/install/
Initial config:

git config --global user.name "Your name"
git config --global user.email "your@email"
Tip: you may use your private GitHub email.
Wait a minute… it’s your first time using Bash… are you panicking?… don’t worry, it’s quite usual… here some tips: https://linuxconfig.org/bash-scripting-tutorial-for-beginners https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/linux-unix/bash-scripting-introduction-to-bash-and-bash-scripting/
First commands: git clone https://github.com/zchuri/ejemplo123.git git log git branch new-branch-name git checkout new-branch-name # switch between branches git checkout main git pull origin main # origin stands for the remote server git merge git push
